page.title: List of amendments to the United States Constitution

revision.text:
{{About|the 33 constitutional amendments approved by Congress and sent to the states for ratification since 1789|proposals to amend the United States Constitution introduced in but ''not'' approved by the U.S. Congress|List of proposed amendments to the United States Constitution}}{{short description|Wikimedia list article}} {{US Constitution article series}}{{United States constitutional law}} Thirty-three '''amendments to the United States Constitution''' have been proposed by the [[United States Congress]] and sent to the [[U.S. state|states]] for [[ratification#Ratification in the United States Constitution|ratification]] since the [[Constitution of the United States|Constitution]] was put into operation on March 4, 1789. Twenty-seven of these, having been ratified by the requisite number of states (38 since 1959), are part of the Constitution. The first ten amendments were adopted and ratified simultaneously and are known collectively as the [[United States Bill of Rights|Bill of Rights]]. Six amendments adopted by Congress and sent to the states have not been ratified by the required number of states. Four of these amendments are still pending, one is closed and has failed by its own terms, and one is closed and has failed by the terms of the resolution proposing it. All 33 amendments are listed and detailed in the tables below. [[Article Five of the United States Constitution]] details the two-step process for [[Constitutional amendment|amending]] the nation's frame of government. Amendments must be properly ''proposed'' and ''ratified'' before becoming operative. This process was designed to strike a balance between the excesses of constant change and inflexibility.{{cite web| last1=England| first1=Trent| last2=Spalding| first2=Matthew| title=Essays on Article V: Amendments| work=The Heritage Guide to The Constitution| url=https://www.heritage.org/constitution/#!/articles/5/essays/129/amendments| publisher=The Heritage Foundation| accessdate=October 29, 2018}} An amendment may be proposed and sent to the states for ratification by either: * The U.S. Congress, whenever a [[two-thirds majority]] in both the [[United States Senate|Senate]] and the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] deem it necessary; or * A [[Convention to propose amendments to the United States Constitution|national convention]], called by Congress for this purpose, on the application of the [[State legislature (United States)|legislatures]] of two-thirds of the states.{{cite web| url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/constitution| title=Constitutional Amendment Process| publisher=U.S. National Archives and Records Administration| location=Washington, D.C.| accessdate=February 22, 2019| date=August 15, 2016}}{{cite web| website=clayton.edu| url=http://www.clayton.edu/arts-sciences/Constitution-Day/Proposed-Amendments| title=Constitution Day: Proposed Amendments| publisher=Clayton State University| location=Morrow, Georgia| accessdate=February 22, 2019}} The convention option has never been used. Convening one would (since 1959) require action by the legislatures of 34 states.{{Cite news| last=Wines| first=Michael| date=August 22, 2016| title=Inside the Conservative Push for States to Amend the Constitution| work=The New York Times| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/23/us/inside-the-conservative-push-for-states-to-amend-the-constitution.amp.html| accessdate=September 27, 2019}} To become part of the Constitution, an amendment must be ratified by either (as determined by Congress): * The legislatures of three-fourths of the states; or * [[State ratifying conventions]] in three-fourths of the states. The only amendment to be ratified through the state convention method thus far is the [[Twenty-first Amendment to the United States Constitution|Twenty-first Amendment]] in 1933. That amendment is also the only one that explicitly repeals an earlier one, the [[Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Eighteenth Amendment]] (ratified in 1919).{{Cite web| title=The Twenty-First Amendment| last1=George| first1=Robert P.| last2=Richards| first2=David A. J| website=constitutioncenter.org| url=https://constitutioncenter.org/interactive-constitution/interpretation/amendment-xxi/interps/151| publisher=National Constitution Center| location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania| accessdate=September 27, 2019}} When a constitutional amendment is sent to the states for ratification, the [[Archivist of the United States]] is charged with responsibility for administering the ratification process under the provisions of {{USC |1|106b}}.{{cite web| last=Huckabee| first=David C.| title=Ratification of Amendments to the U.S. Constitution| url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metacrs415/m1/1/high_res_d/97-922gov_1997Sep30.pdf| work=[[Congressional Research Service reports]] (97-922 GOV)| publisher= [[Congressional Research Service]], The [[Library of Congress]]| location=Washington D.C.| date=September 30, 1997| accessdate=February 23, 2019| via=University of North Texas Digital Library}} Then, upon being properly ratified, the archivist issues a certificate [[Promulgation|proclaiming]] that an amendment has become an operative part of the Constitution. Beginning in the early 20th century, Congress has usually, but not always, stipulated that an amendment must be ratified by the required number of states within seven years from the date of its submission to the states in order to become part of the Constitution. Congress's authority to set a ratification deadline was affirmed in 1939 by the [[United States Supreme Court]] in ''[[Coleman v. Miller]]'' ({{ussc|307|433}}). Approximately 11,770 proposals to amend the Constitution have been introduced in Congress since 1789 (as of January 3, 2019).{{cite web|title=Measures Proposed to Amend the Constitution|url=https://www.senate.gov/pagelayout/reference/three_column_table/measures_proposed_to_amend_constitution.htm|publisher=Office of the Secretary, United States Senate|location=Washington, D.C.|accessdate=March 16, 2019}} Collectively, members of the [[United States House of Representatives|House]] and [[United States Senate|Senate]] typically propose around 200 amendments during each two-year term of Congress.{{cite web|url=http://www.c-span.org/questions/weekly54.asp|title=C-SPAN's Capitol Questions|date=June 9, 2000|accessdate=October 29, 2018|url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509141821/http://www.c-span.org/questions/weekly54.asp |archivedate=May 9, 2008}} Proposals have covered numerous topics, but none made in recent decades have become part of the Constitution. Historically, most died in the [[United States congressional committee|congressional committees]] to which they were assigned. Since 1999, only about 20 proposed amendments have received a vote by either the full House or Senate. The last time a proposal gained the necessary two-thirds support in both the House and the Senate for submission to the states was the [[District of Columbia Voting Rights Amendment]] in 1978. Only 16 states had ratified it when the seven-year time limit expired.{{Cite web| last=DeSilver| first=Drew| date=April 12, 2018| url=https://pewrsr.ch/2valfIc| website=pewresearch.org| title=Proposed amendments to the U.S. Constitution seldom go anywhere|orig-year=Update, originally published September 17, 2014| accessdate=September 27, 2019}} ==Ratified amendments== {{clear}} ===Synopsis of each ratified amendment=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! rowspan=2|No. ! rowspan=2|Subject ! colspan=3|Ratification{{cite web|title=The Bill of Rights|url=https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs/bill-of-rights|work=America's Founding Documents|publisher=National Archives|location=Washington, D.C.|accessdate=October 29, 2018|date=2015-10-31}}{{cite web|title=The Constitution: Amendments 11-27|url=https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs/amendments-11-27|work=America's Founding Documents|publisher=National Archives|location=Washington, D.C.|accessdate=October 29, 2018|date=2015-11-04}} |- ! class="unsortable"|Proposed ! class="unsortable"|Completed ! style="width:95pt;" | Title ! style="width:280pt;" | Subject ! style="width:200pt;" | Status |-style="vertical-align: top;" | [[Congressional Apportionment Amendment]] | Would strictly regulate the size of [[List of United States congressional districts|congressional districts]] for representation in the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]]. | Pending since September 25, 1789 |-style="vertical-align: top;" | [[Titles of Nobility Amendment]] | Would strip [[Citizenship in the United States|citizenship]] from any United States citizen who accepts a title of [[nobility]] from a foreign country. | Pending since May 1, 1810 |-style="vertical-align: top;" |[[Corwin Amendment]] | Would make the states' "domestic institutions" ([[slavery]]) [[entrenched clause|impervious]] to the constitutional amendment procedures established in [[Article Five of the United States Constitution|Article V]] and immune to abolition or interference from Congress. | Pending since March 2, 1861 |-style="vertical-align: top;" |[[Child Labor Amendment]] | Would empower the federal government to limit, regulate, and prohibit [[child labor]]. | Pending since June 2, 1924 |-style="vertical-align: top; background:#f3f3f3" | [[Equal Rights Amendment]] | Would have prohibited deprivation of [[discrimination|equality of rights]] by the federal or state governments on account of sex. | Initial ratification period ended March 22, 1979, and extension period ended June 30, 1982; amendment failed (''status challenged''){{efn|Three states have ratified the ERA in recent years (Virginia, Illinois and Nevada), purportedly bringing the number of ratifications to 38. In January 2020, after the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] issued an opinion that the deadline for passage of the amendment expired at the time of the original 1979 deadline, the [[State attorney general|attorneys general]] of those three states filed suit in [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit|U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C.]] challenging that opinion. As reported by [[CNN]], they are asking the court to force the archivist of the United States to "carry out his statutory duty of recognizing the complete and final adoption" of the ERA as the 28th Amendment to the Constitution.{{Cite news| url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/30/politics/equal-rights-amendment-virginia-litigation-trnd/index.html| title=Three Democratic attorneys general sue to have Equal Rights Amendment added to Constitution| first=Veronica| last=Stracqualursi |website=[[CNN]]| date=January 30, 2020| accessdate=January 31, 2020}}}} |-style="vertical-align: top; background:#e6e6e6" | [[District of Columbia Voting Rights Amendment]] | Would have treated the [[District of Columbia]] as if it were a state regarding representation in the United States Congress (including repealing the [[Twenty-third Amendment to the United States Constitution|23rd Amendment]]), representation in the Electoral College and participation in the process by which the Constitution is amended. | Ratification period ended August 22, 1985; amendment failed |-style="background:#f3f3f3" |colspan=3|{{notelist}} |} ===Summation of ratification data for each unratified amendment=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="vertical-align: bottom;" |- | colspan=7 |Y indicates that state ratified amendment |- | colspan=7 |N indicates that state rejected amendment |- | colspan=7 |Y(‡) indicates that state ratified amendment after first rejecting it |- | colspan=7 |Y(×) indicates that state ratified amendment, but later rescinded that ratification |- | colspan=7 |⋈ indicates that state did not complete action on amendment during stated ratification period. |- | colspan=7 |⋈''Y'' indicates that state ratified amendment after stated ratification period. |- | colspan=7 |"{{0|00}}" An empty cell indicates that state has not completed action on pending amendment. |- style="vertical-align: bottom;" !
